text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- At least 56 percent of 420,238 candidates who sat national examinations in 1996 will miss secondary school because of a shortage of places.
- Five members of parliament from the oppostion FORD-Kenya party allied to faction leader Raila Odinga say they will not join him in defecting to another party.
- Education minister Joseph Kamotho says the government will ensure pupils from private primary schools do not receive admission to national secondary schools before those from state schools.
- Twelve members of an unregistered religious sect appear in a Kisii court charged with being followers of an unlawful society.
- A Nairobi court hears police have not begun investigating the killing of two Kenyatta University students shot dead on December 18.
- Police warn pharmacies and chemists from buying suspected expired drugs stolen in transit from Mombasa to Uganda.
- A four-man gang walks into a Nairobi hospital and takes more than 800,000 shillings in cash.
- President Daniel arap Moi urges government officers to speed up issuing of second generation national identification cards to beat a January 31 deadline.
- Raila Odinga's move from the wrangle-ridden FORD-Kenya to National Development Party of Kenya is expected to strengthen opposition democratic forces.
- Battles between two feuding factions of the ruling Kenya African National Union spread to the coastal town of Mombasa. ($1=55 Kenyan Shillings)
